questions.text: Which of the following is not a derivative of neural crest cells?
questions.explanation:
Structure

Neural Crest Origin

Ciliary muscles

Derived from neural crest

Ciliary ganglion

Derived from neural crest

Melanocytes

Derived from neural crest

Retinal pigment epithelium (RPE)

Derived from neural ectoderm

questions.text: Which of the following arises from 6th pharyngeal arch?
questions.explanation:
Arch

Nerve of arch

Artery of arch

Skeletal derivatives

Muscles of arch

(Options A, B, and D)

First

 

Maxillary (Sensory) and mandibular (Motor and sensory) branches of trigeminal nerve

Maxillary artery
  • Meckel's cartilage
    • Malleus
    • Incus
    • Anterior ligament of malleus
    • Sphenomandibular ligament
  • Mandible
  • Maxilla
  • Zygomatic
  • Palatine
  • Temporal (part)

 
  • Masseter
  • Temporalis
  • Medial pterygoid
  • Lateral pterygoids
  • Mylohyoid
  • Anterior belly of digastric
  • Tensor tympani, and
  • Tensor palati

 

All are migratory except T. tympani

Second

Facial nerve
  • Hyoid artery
  • Stapedial artery

The cartilage of the second arch (Reichert’s) forms the

Following:

  • Stapes
  • Styloid process
  • Stylohyoid ligament
  • Lesser cornu of hyoid
  • Upper half of body of hyoid
  • Stapedius
  • Stylohyoid
  • Posterior belly of digastric
  • Epicranius
  • Orbicularis oculi
  • Orbicularis oris
  • Zygomaticus
  • Buccinator
  • Nasal muscles
  • Platysma
  • Levator labii superioris, levator labii inferioris
  • Levator anguli oris
  • Auricular muscles

 

All are migratory except stapedius, stylohyoid

Third

Glossopharyngeal nerve
  • Common carotid artery
  • Internal carotid artery
  • Greater cornu of hyoid
  • Lower half of body of hyoid

 

Stylopharyngeus

Fourth

Superior laryngeal branch of vagus nerve
  • Arch of aorta (left side)
  • Subclavian artery (right side)
  • Thyroid
  • Cricoid
  • Corniculate
  • Cuneiform
  • Arytenoid
  • Thyrohyoid ligament
  • Epiglottis—from mesodermal core of hypobranchial eminence
  • Larynx–Cricothyroid
  • Muscles of pharynx
  • Intrinsic muscles of soft palate except tensor palati

Sixth

Recurrent laryngeal branch of vagus nerve
  • Ductus arteriosus (left side)
  • Pulmonary artery (right side)

All intrinsic muscles of larynx except cricothyroid

questions.text: Meiosis occurs in:
Identify the structure marked in the diagram showing the development of ovarian follicles.
questions.explanation:
Stage

Characteristics

Primordial follicle

Oocytes surrounded by a single layer of flattened granulosa cells. Dormant until puberty.

Primary follicle

Granulosa cells become cuboidal, zona pellucida begins forming around the oocyte. No antrum.

Secondary follicle

Multiple layers of granulosa cells and theca cells form. Early follicular development but no antrum yet.

Antral follicle

Fluid-filled antrum appears, granulosa and theca cells differentiate. Prepares for ovulation.

Graafian follicle

Fully matured, large antrum, ready for ovulation.

Corpus luteum

Formed after ovulation, secretes progesterone to support pregnancy. If there is no fertilization, it degenerates.

questions.text: On what is the SRY gene located?
Absence or mutation of SRY gene results in ?
Which of the following structures develop from the 6th pharyngeal arch artery on the left side?
questions.explanation:
Pharyngeal Arch

Artery of Arch

First

Maxillary artery

Second

Hyoid artery, Stapedial artery

Third

Common carotid artery, Internal carotid artery

Fourth

Arch of aorta (left side), Subclavian artery (right side)

Sixth

Ductus arteriosus (left side), Pulmonary artery (right side)

questions.text: Implantation occurs on which day post fertilization?
questions.explanation:
Stage

Day (Post-Fertilization)

Key Event

Fertilization

Day 0

Sperm fertilizes oocyte in ampulla of fallopian tube

Zygote Formation

Day 1

Single-cell zygote undergoes cleavage

Morula Formation

Day 3-4

16-cell stage compacted into a solid ball

Blastocyst Formation

Day 5

Fluid-filled cavity forms; blastocyst reaches the uterus

Implantation Begins

Day 5-6

Blastocyst attaches to the endometrium

Trophoblast Invasion

Day 6-8

Syncytiotrophoblast formation, hCG secretion begins

Complete Implantation

Day 9-10

Blastocyst is fully embedded in the endometrial lining

questions.text: Post ovulation the oocyte is:
questions.correct_answer: D. Secondary oocyte arrested in metaphase- 2
questions.explanation: Correct Option D - Secondary oocyte arrested in metaphase-2

questions.text: The covering of an omphalocele is derived from which layer?
questions.explanation: Correct Option A - A

questions.text: Which of the following prevents polyspermy?
questions.explanation: Correct Option B - Cortical

questions.text: Identify the marked structure:
questions.explanation:
Stage

Description

Formation

Appears on day 15 of development as a linear thickening in the epiblast of the bilaminar disc.

Function

Acts as a site for epiblast cell migration, which forms the mesoderm and endoderm.

Regression

By the end of the 4th week, the primitive streak regresses, leaving behind the notochord and mesoderm.

Clinical Significance

If it fails to regress, it may lead to sacrococcygeal teratoma (tumor with all three germ layers).

questions.text: Which of the following is the 1st to be formed by the migration of the epiblast along the primitive streak?
questions.explanation:
Stage

Description

Primitive Streak Formation

Forms along the midline of the epiblast, marking the site of cell migration.

Endoderm Formation

The first wave of migrating epiblast cells replaces the hypoblast to form the definitive endoderm, which later gives rise to the gut and associated organs.

Mesoderm Formation

Subsequent migration of epiblast cells forms the mesoderm, which differentiates into structures like the cardiac mesoderm and notochord.

Ectoderm Formation

Epiblast cells that do not migrate remain as ectoderm, which later forms the epidermis and neural structures.

questions.text: A newborn had hypoplasia of the mandibles and zygomatic bones, malformed external ears, and slanted palpebral fissures. Abnormality in the development of which of the following pharyngeal arches will most likely lead to the given condition?
questions.explanation: Correct Option A

questions.text: Which of the following is false about skin?

options.label: B
options.text: Skin accounts for 15% of total body weight

options.label: D
options.text: Dermis is made up of type 1 and type 3 collagen

questions.correct_answer: A. Dermis is derived from ectoderm

questions.text: 1 st pharyngeal arch gives rise to all except:
questions.explanation:
Correct Option B - Levator v

Pharyngeal Arch

Structures Derived

1st Pharyngeal Arch

Maxillary process, Mandibular process, Meckel's cartilage, Muscles of mastication (Temporalis, Masseter, Medial and Lateral pterygoids), Mylohyoid, Anterior belly of digastric, Tensor tympani, Tensor veli palatini

2nd Pharyngeal Arch

Reichert's cartilage, Stapes, Styloid process, Stylohyoid ligament, Muscles of facial expression, Posterior belly of digastric, Stapedius

3rd Pharyngeal Arch

Hyoid bone, Greater horn, Lower part of body, Stylopharyngeus muscle

4th Pharyngeal Arch

Thyroid cartilage, Cricoid cartilage, Levator veli palatini, Cricothyroid muscle

6th Pharyngeal Arch

Laryngeal cartilages (except thyroid and cricoid), Intrinsic muscles of the larynx

questions.text: Ureteric bud develops from:
questions.explanation:
Correct Option A - Mesonephric du

Structure

Developmental Origin

Function/Significance

Ureteric bud

Mesonephric duct

Arises from the mesonephric duct (Wolffian duct)

 

 

Gives rise to the ureter, renal pelvis,calyces, and collecting ducts

Metanephric mesenchyme

Metanephric mesenchyme

Interacts with the ureteric bud to form the kidney

Pronephros

Pronephric mesoderm

Regresses early in development and does not

contribute to the formation of the ureteric bud

Genital sinus

Endodermal tissue

Involved in the development of the urogenital

system, including bladder and urethra

questions.text: During which developmental week does the heartbeat initiate in the cardiac region?
questions.explanation:
Correct Option B - 4

Developmental Stage

Heartbeat

3rd week of gestation (21-22 days)

Begins as a simple tubular structure and initiates spontaneous contractions

4th week of gestation

Heart tube undergoes looping, and the heart starts beating rhythmically

5th week of gestation

Heart chambers begin to form, and the heart rate increases

8th week of gestation

Four-chambered heart is well-formed, and heartbeat can be detected using ultrasound

9th-10th week of gestation

Heartbeat becomes more regular and coordinated

End of 12th week of gestation

Fetal heart rate can be heard using a Doppler device

questions.text: Type I collagen is not seen in –
questions.explanation:
Correct Option D

Collagen Type

Main Location

Function

Type I

Skin, bone, tendons

Provides tensile strength and structural support

Type II

Cartilage

Provides structural support and resilience

Type III

Blood vessels, skin

Supports the structure of blood vessels

Type IV

Basement membranes

Forms a scaffold for cells and filtration

Type V

Connective tissues

Modulates the assembly of type I collagen

Type VII

Epidermis

Anchors the epidermis to the dermis

Type XI

Cartilage, intervertebral discs

Provides structural support and organization

questions.text: Meissner corpuscles are present in:-
questions.explanation: Correct Option A

questions.text: The structure marked with the asterisk in the electron micrograph indicates
questions.explanation:
Correct Option C

Cell Organelle

Appearance on Electron Microscopy

Nucleus

Dense spherical structure with a double membrane and dark-stained chromatin inside.

Mitochondria

Oval or rod-shaped structures with a double membrane and internal cristae.

Endoplasmic reticulum

A network of interconnected membranous tubules and flattened sacs, often appearing as sheets or cisternae.

Golgi apparatus

Stack of flattened membranous sacs (cisternae) with small vesicles nearby.

Lysosomes

Spherical vesicles with a single membrane containing various enzymes. They may contain electron-dense materials inside.

Ribosomes

Tiny granular structures scattered throughout the cytoplasm or attached to the endoplasmic reticulum.

Cytoskeleton

A network of protein filaments (microfilaments, intermediate filaments, and microtubules) extending throughout the cell.

Vesicles

Small membranous sacs involved in transporting substances within the cell or to the cell membrane.
